description: From the Latin apodīcticus (“proving clearly”, “demonstrative”), from the Ancient Greek ἀποδεικτικός (apodeiktikós, “affording proof”, “demonstrative”), from ἀποδείκνυμι (apodeíknumi, “I demonstrate”). In turn, from ἀπο- (apo-, “separate, without”), and δεικτικός (deiktikós, “capable of proof”).

adjectives.description: apodictic (comparative more apodictic, superlative most apodictic)

examples: No religion has ever yet owed its prevalence to ‘apodictic certainty’.

entries.meaning: Being a style of argument in which a person presents their reasoning as categorically true, even if it is not necessarily so.
examples: Don't be so apodictic! You haven't considered several facets of the question.

entries.meaning: (theology, Biblical studies) Absolute and without explanation, as in a command from God like "Thou shalt not kill!"
